titleStmt.title: The Description of an Irish Feast Translated
almost letterally out of the original Iris by Dean

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: O Ruark's noble Fare, will ne'er be forgot by those who were there, or those who were not
His Revells to keep, we sup & we Dineon seven score Sheep, fat Bullocks and Swine
Usquebaugh to our feast, in pails was brought upan hundred at least, and 1awooden vessell a madder our Cup
O There is the sport, we rise with the Lightin disorderly sort, from snoring all night
O how was I trick't, my Pipe it was brokemy pocket was pick't, I lost my new Cloak
I'm rifled quoth Nell, of Mantle and Kercherwhy then fare them well, the Dee'l take the Searcher
Come harper strikeup, but first by your favourBoy giveus a Cup, ay, this has some savour
O Ruark's jolly Boys, ne'er dream't ofthe matter'till rowz'd by the noise, & musical clatter
They bounce from their nest, no longer will tarrythey rise ready drest, without one Ave Mary
They dance in around, cutting Capers and rampinga mercy the ground, did not burst with their stamping
The floor is all wet, with leap & with jumpswhile the water & sweat, splish splash in their pumps
Bless you late and early, Laughlin o Enekeenby my hand you dance rarely, Margery Greenagan
Bring straw for our bed, shake it down to the feetthen over us spread the winnowing Sheet
To shew I dont flinch, fill the Bowl up againthen give us a pinch, of your sneezing 2an Irish name for a woman. i.e. Hanah.a yean
Good Lord what a sight ?after erased all their good cheerfor people to fight in the midst of their Beer
They rise from their feast, & hot are their Brainsa Cubit at least, the length of their skeans
What stab's and what Cuts, with clattering of Stickswhat stroke's on the Guts, what basting and Kicks
With Cudgels of Oak, well harden'd in flamean hundred heads broke, an hundred struck lame
You churl I'll maintain, my father built Luskthe Castle of Slane, and Carrick Drumrusk
The Earl of Kildare, and Moynalta his brotheras great as they are, I was nurs'd by their mother
Ask that of old Madam, she'll tell you who's who.as far up as Adam. She knows it is true
Come down with that Beam, if Cudgels be scarcea blow on the Weam, and a Kick on the A──se244-202I
